docs.snippet: THE berry season has arrived. Strawberries to purchase at farm stands or to gather at farms that permit pickers are the first of a succession of locally grown berries that ripen through the fall.   After the strawberries come raspberries and blueb...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE berry season has arrived. Strawberries to purchase at farm stands or to gather at farms that permit pickers are the first of a succession of locally grown berries that ripen through the fall. After the strawberries come raspberries and blueberries, then blackberries, then raspberries again. Finally, some areas will have locally grown cranberries.

headline.main: Salute Berries in Ways Plain and Fancy

docs.snippet: IF you are celebrating Easter with a ham today, tomorrow you will be thinking about leftovers. This I learned one Easter years ago after baking a country ham in a motel kitchenette down South.   A friend and I were on the way to Mexico by car (Vol...
docs.lead_paragraph: IF you are celebrating Easter with a ham today, tomorrow you will be thinking about leftovers. This I learned one Easter years ago after baking a country ham in a motel kitchenette down South. A friend and I were on the way to Mexico by car (Volkswagen bus, in fact, de riguer in those days), when I came across the famous cured country hams I had read about, hanging in a shop in Tennessee. I couldn't resist buying one, with the result that the two of us sat down for an Easter dinner that consisted of a ham weighing more than 16 pounds. For the next few days we cheerfully tucked into ham sandwiches, but they barely made a dent in our enormous country ham. It didn't take long before our daily ration of the stuff was no longer a pleasure, but a baleful reminder of my extravagance. I began thinking of every conceivable way of finishing up the ham: stuffing it into enchiladas, dousing it with chilis, submerging chunks of it in stews, poaching it with Mornay sauce and hiding it under eggs.

headline.main: Italian Dishes Make Good Use of the Leftover Ham

docs.snippet: LEAD: NO one thinks twice about buying chicken in parts, but few places will sell you duck legs or breasts separately. This is too bad, for when it comes to cooking duck, most people do it one way: in the oven. The problem with roasting is that wh...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: NO one thinks twice about buying chicken in parts, but few places will sell you duck legs or breasts separately. This is too bad, for when it comes to cooking duck, most people do it one way: in the oven. The problem with roasting is that when the legs are done, the breast is often dry. If the breast is pink, the legs are red.

headline.main: If Only Ducks Were Sold in Parts

headline.main: Preparing Classic Italian Dishes, but With a Twist

docs.snippet: LEAD: Pork medallions snuggled next to creamy, garlicky potatoes. Prime rib rubbed with olive paste. Chocolate-stuffed croissants soaked with creme anglaise. This is California cuisine - a far cry from the raw baby vegetables, edible flowers and p...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Pork medallions snuggled next to creamy, garlicky potatoes. Prime rib rubbed with olive paste. Chocolate-stuffed croissants soaked with creme anglaise. This is California cuisine - a far cry from the raw baby vegetables, edible flowers and pizzas that put the state on the culinary map. And while pork, potatoes and bread pudding may seem at odds with the trim, tanned population, restaurants that serve robust food are experiencing a mini-revival.

docs.snippet: LEAD: DO people who live in the country spend more time in their kitchens than city dwellers? Manhattan apartment kitchens are so often like mine - an afterthought tucked away in a hall closet, the brilliant coup of some architect determined to ma...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: DO people who live in the country spend more time in their kitchens than city dwellers? Manhattan apartment kitchens are so often like mine - an afterthought tucked away in a hall closet, the brilliant coup of some architect determined to make two tight little apartments fit where one would have been perfectly comfortable.

docs.snippet: CELERY root, also known as celeriac, is not a pretty vegetable. It is an ugly, gnarled ball with a nobbly skin. But underneath is an ivory flesh much like a potato, with a delicate hint of celery. It is a natural accompaniment to holiday roasts an...
docs.abstract: Moira Hodgson Food column on preparing dishes with celery root; recipes; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: CELERY root, also known as celeriac, is not a pretty vegetable. It is an ugly, gnarled ball with a nobbly skin. But underneath is an ivory flesh much like a potato, with a delicate hint of celery. It is a natural accompaniment to holiday roasts and game, mashed or sliced and baked in the oven. The French chef, Roger Verge, grates celery root and makes it into crisp pancakes, which he serves topped with thin slices of onion, celery hearts and creme fraiche. This dish, which is from the Dauphine region of France, is wonderful on its own or with leftover meat.

headline.main: Getting Under the Unattractive Skin of Celery Root

docs.snippet: SAFFRON is not only the world's costliest spice, it also  probably deserves a mention in the Guinness Book of World Records as the most expensive ingredient of any kind. Around $5 a gram for the best quality, it is more expensive than white truffl...
docs.abstract: Florence Fabricant Food column offers recipes in which saffron is important for its flavor as well as color; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: SAFFRON is not only the world's costliest spice, it also probably deserves a mention in the Guinness Book of World Records as the most expensive ingredient of any kind. Around $5 a gram for the best quality, it is more expensive than white truffles or beluga caviar. But a little of this precious seasoning, which adds a rich canary color in addition to a tantalizing hint of pungent, slightly smoky flavor, goes a very long way. The average recipe using saffron rarely requires more than a half-teaspoon of the filaments, a fraction of a gram. Most often, saffron is associated with Spanish cooking. In fact, the very best saffron, which is from the stamens of the purple autumn crocus, comes from Spain, where about 70 percent of the world's saffron is grown.

headline.main: A Pinch of Saffron Adds Smoky Flavor

docs.snippet: AS I was shopping in a country supermarket, a woman at the meat counter said to me, ''I've been shopping here for 10 years, and you're only the second person I've ever seen buy rabbit.'' I was surprised. Several years ago it was hard to find fresh...
docs.abstract: Moira Hodgson Food column offers recipes in which rabbit can be substituted for chicken; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: AS I was shopping in a country supermarket, a woman at the meat counter said to me, ''I've been shopping here for 10 years, and you're only the second person I've ever seen buy rabbit.'' I was surprised. Several years ago it was hard to find fresh rabbit in stores, but now it is widely available. It is also showing up with increasing frequency in restaurants. Chefs like it because it has more taste than chicken and adapts easily to all kinds of seasoning. Home cooks may be daunted because they assume rabbit is difficult to cook. In fact, it is no more complicated than chicken. If you are cutting it up yourself, leave the back legs whole or divide them into thighs and drumsticks. Leave the front legs whole. Cut the saddle in two. The saddle is the most tender part.

headline.main: Try Rabbit Sauteed, Baked or Grilled Instead of Chicken

docs.snippet: SAUSAGES and potatoes are the ultimate comfort food. I grew up in England where the combination is called bangers and mash, the quintessential Sunday dinner on a chilly winter night. Another favorite was toad in the hole, a dish most Americans mig...
docs.abstract: Food column on sausage and potato dishes; recipes; drawing (M)/
docs.lead_paragraph: SAUSAGES and potatoes are the ultimate comfort food. I grew up in England where the combination is called bangers and mash, the quintessential Sunday dinner on a chilly winter night. Another favorite was toad in the hole, a dish most Americans might not find comforting at all, since it consists of sausages baked under a thick layer of batter. But the British have always taken great pride in their bangers. You can still find some pretty nasty ones, made with rusk filler and artificial coloring, but now butchers are more likely to offer a variety of plump, glossy sausages, often made from old regional recipes. In London over the holidays, I went to Harrod's food hall, where my son spied wild boar sausages. Since he is a fan of the ''Asterix'' books, in which every adventure is brought to a happy conclusion over a meal of wild boar, we had to have them. They were delicious, stuffed with herbs and apples, which kept them moist.

headline.main: Ah, Sausage and Noble Potato, a Marriage Made in Heaven
